name: Karelian Reindeer
description: The Karelian reindeer has a gray to gray-brown coloration and relatively long legs. Compared to domesticated reindeer, it is generally larger and slimmer.
food_note: Lichens, mosses, leaves, and tree bark
image_alt: Karelian Reindeer, photo: Tomáš Adamec, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 120–220 cm; tail length 7–21 cm; shoulder height 84–130 cm; weight 90–250 kg
reproduction: Females are pregnant for 210–240 days and usually give birth to one calf.
attractions: The reindeer is the only deer species in which females also have antlers, though they are somewhat weaker than those of males. They are well-equipped for life in harsh conditions. Dense fur protects them from the cold, and long, wide hooves prevent them from sinking into deep snow. The rare Karelian subspecies lives wild in Finland and Russian Karelia. In Finland, this subspecies was completely wiped out at the beginning of the 20th century and only began to spread back into its original homeland from Russia starting in the late 1940s.
breeding: We’ve kept them since 2013. The herd at Prague Zoo is only the second in the Czech Republic.
